abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Third Industrial Restructuring Project
            in Hungary. The overall outcome of the project was rated
            satisfactory; the performance of the Bank and the borrower
            was also rated satisfactory. The project's objective
            was to support the restructuring of the industrial sector in
            order to enhance its international competitiveness. Some of
            the lessons from this experience are as follows: (a) the
            rapidly changing political, social, and economic environment
            in Hungary had a decisive impact on project performance,
            both positive and negative. While it was hardly possible to
            anticipate the dramatic changes, reaction to changing
            situations could have been swifter. Given the evolving
            nature of the reform process, several years of experience
            with Bank financed activities, plus availability of
            additional sources of external finance, it may have been
            opportune for the Bank and the Hungarian authorities to have
            reviewed the overall strategy for, and comparative
            advantages of, Bank assistance much earlier in the project
            life. This assertion is not intended to imply that all was
            wrong and needed to be changed, but rather that, in light of
            all the changes that took place, a fresh look may have
            optimized the benefits of Bank assistance. (b)The project
            design included too many components and eligibility criteria
            (for credit lines), that made project monitoring and
            implementation difficult under the prevailing political,
            social, and economic conditions. Implementation became much
            smoother, once the Loan Agreement was amended and procedures
            were made simplified.
